list_definition.definition: to move (a door, window, lid etc) so that it covers or fills an opening; to move (a drawer, book etc) so that it is no longer open

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: Shut your eyes and don’t look.
The window shut with a bang.

list_definition.definition: to close and usually lock (a building etc) eg at the end of the day or when people no longer work there

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The shops all shut at half past five
There’s a rumour that the factory is going to be shut.

list_definition.definition: to keep in or out of some place or keep away from someone by shutting something

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The dog was shut inside the house.
Make sure the gate is shut when you leave.

list_ex_of_english: Thus, indigenous peoples often referred to a history that had led to their marginal position and to their being shut out of decision-making.
Although the copy numbers of the vector genome were reduced, our data did not rule out promoter shut-off completely.
I am not sure the field is in much danger of shutting itself off through single-author books.
After the guests' departure from the third camp the establishment was shut down and cleaned professionally before reopening.
In a real application of this system, the failed component can be shut down when a failure is detected.
Parasites and parasitoids often shut down host investment in reproduction which is wasteful from the parasite's point of view.
The present results indicate that a step is a single photon response with an aberrant long-lasting shut-off mechanism.
The exponential distribution of step durations suggests that the shut-off of activated rhodopsin under these conditions is rate limited by a single first-order process.
